articles.headline: Ginsburg Says Her Cancer Has Returned, but She’s ‘Fully Able’ to Remain on Court
articles.snippet: The announcement touches off speculation about the possibility of a court opening as both parties seek to make the future of the Supreme Court an election issue.
articles.abstract: The announcement touches off speculation about the possibility of a court opening as both parties seek to make the future of the Supreme Court an election issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the most prominent member of the Supreme Court’s liberal minority, said Friday that she has had a recurrence of cancer, causing a wave of anxiety among Democrats that was not completely assuaged by her assurance that she was undergoing chemotherapy, with “positive results,” and would remain on the Supreme Court.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak, Denise Grady and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: No Bleach and Dirty Rags: How Some Janitors Are Asked to Keep You Virus-Free
articles.snippet: Planes are wiped in under 10 minutes. Many custodians have to bring their own supplies. Yet as the U.S. reopens, companies are boasting of high safety standards to lure customers.
articles.abstract: Planes are wiped in under 10 minutes. Many custodians have to bring their own supplies. Yet as the U.S. reopens, companies are boasting of high safety standards to lure customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The old job of custodians was tidying up. The new one is protecting against a killer through disinfection.

articles.headline: Are You Eligible for Food Stamps Now? Maybe, but It’s Complex
articles.snippet: States run SNAP, and many students and older people don’t realize they’re eligible. Without more federal support, millions more may qualify.
articles.abstract: States run SNAP, and many students and older people don’t realize they’re eligible. Without more federal support, millions more may qualify.
articles.lead_paragraph: The safety net is starting to unravel.

articles.headline: Hackers Tell the Story of the Twitter Attack From the Inside
articles.snippet: Several people involved in the events that took down Twitter this week spoke with The Times, giving the first account of what happened as a pursuit of Bitcoin spun out of control.
articles.abstract: Several people involved in the events that took down Twitter this week spoke with The Times, giving the first account of what happened as a pursuit of Bitcoin spun out of control.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — A Twitter hacking scheme that targeted political, corporate and cultural elites this week began with a teasing message between two hackers late Tuesday on the online messaging platform Discord.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Kate Conger

articles.headline: John Lewis, Towering Figure of Civil Rights Era, Dies at 80
articles.snippet: Images of his beating at Selma shocked the nation and led to swift passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. He was later called the conscience of the Congress.
articles.abstract: Images of his beating at Selma shocked the nation and led to swift passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. He was later called the conscience of the Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis, a son of sharecroppers and an apostle of nonviolence who was bloodied at Selma and across the Jim Crow South in the historic struggle for racial equality, and who then carried a mantle of moral authority into Congress, died on Friday. He was 80.

articles.headline: How PG&E Is Racing to Improve Safety as Fire Season Approaches
articles.snippet: The utility, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, is upgrading power lines, trimming trees and making other changes to prevent another big fire.
articles.abstract: The utility, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, is upgrading power lines, trimming trees and making other changes to prevent another big fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — Atop an electrical pole overlooking grapevines, Pacific Gas & Electric recently installed a piece of equipment that will allow it to quickly turn off power to this part of California’s wine country when conditions for a wildfire are just right.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Jim Wilson

articles.headline: Officer Who Pressed His Knee on George Floyd’s Neck Drew Scrutiny Long Before
articles.snippet: In more than 19 years on the Minneapolis police force, Mr. Chauvin had a reputation as a rigid workaholic with few friends. He sometimes made other officers uncomfortable.
articles.abstract: In more than 19 years on the Minneapolis police force, Mr. Chauvin had a reputation as a rigid workaholic with few friends. He sometimes made other officers uncomfortable.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The four teenagers drove around playing a game of Nerf Gun Assassin on a May evening before graduation in 2013. One of them randomly fired an orange dart out the window.
articles.byline: By Kim Barker and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Inside Trump’s Failure: The Rush to Abandon Leadership Role on the Virus
articles.snippet: The roots of the nation’s current inability to control the pandemic can be traced to mid-April, when the White House embraced overly rosy projections to proclaim victory and move on.
articles.abstract: The roots of the nation’s current inability to control the pandemic can be traced to mid-April, when the White House embraced overly rosy projections to proclaim victory and move on.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Noah Weiland, Eric Lipton, Maggie Haberman and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: How Buying Beans Became a Political Statement
articles.snippet: The boycott and counter-boycott of Goya come as the major political parties seek to energize Hispanic support ahead of the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: The boycott and counter-boycott of Goya come as the major political parties seek to energize Hispanic support ahead of the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the Goya brand was synonymous with the Latino-American dream. The sheer number of products that lined the grocery store aisles — from refried pinto beans to sazón con azafran seasoning — spoke to the growing number of Hispanic immigrants who bought them. Goya, the nation’s largest Hispanic food company, has sponsored Dominican art shows, mariachi contests and soccer programs.
articles.byline: By Farah Stockman, Kate Kelly and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: The Week in Business: Twitter’s Mystery Hackers
articles.snippet: Twitter’s hackers could have made chaos. Why didn’t they?
articles.abstract: Twitter’s hackers could have made chaos. Why didn’t they?
articles.lead_paragraph: Good morning. A financial tip: When someone on the internet asks for Bitcoin and promises double your money back, it’s probably a lie. Here’s what else you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead.

articles.headline: As Trump Ignores Virus Crisis, Republicans Start to Break Ranks
articles.snippet: President Trump continues to press for a quick return to life as usual, but Republicans who fear a rampaging disease and angry voters are increasingly going their own way.
articles.abstract: President Trump continues to press for a quick return to life as usual, but Republicans who fear a rampaging disease and angry voters are increasingly going their own way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Special Interests Mobilize to Get Piece of Next Virus Relief Package
articles.snippet: Congress is about to start negotiating in earnest over another round of stimulus, and a frenzy of lobbying is already underway.
articles.abstract: Congress is about to start negotiating in earnest over another round of stimulus, and a frenzy of lobbying is already underway.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Airlines, hotels and restaurants. Military contractors and banks. Even Broadway actors. These are just a few of the special interests already maneuvering to get a piece of the next coronavirus relief package about to be taken up by Congress.

articles.headline: Vulnerable Border Community Battles Virus on ‘A Straight Up Trajectory’
articles.snippet: In the Rio Grande Valley, poverty and chronic illness are aggravating the coronavirus outbreak. Ambulances stack up outside emergency rooms, where patients wait for beds.
articles.abstract: In the Rio Grande Valley, poverty and chronic illness are aggravating the coronavirus outbreak. Ambulances stack up outside emergency rooms, where patients wait for beds.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDINBURG, Texas — On a sweltering day last week near the southern tip of Texas, where high rates of poverty and chronic illness have heightened the ferocity of the coronavirus, Dr. Renzo Arauco Brown made his rounds, checking on patients who were facing severe complications from the virus and barely hanging on to life.
articles.byline: By Caitlin Dickerson and Lynsey Addario

articles.headline: Amid a Deadly Virus and Crippled Economy, One Form of Aid Has Proved Reliable: Food Stamps
articles.snippet: In the first three months of the coronavirus pandemic, more than six million people joined a program the Trump administration tried to cut.
articles.abstract: In the first three months of the coronavirus pandemic, more than six million people joined a program the Trump administration tried to cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than six million people enrolled in food stamps in the first three months of the coronavirus pandemic, an unprecedented expansion that is likely to continue as more jobless people deplete their savings and billions in unemployment aid expires this month.

articles.headline: An Ex-Times Reporter. An Ohio Wedding Provider. Covid Contrarians Go Viral.
articles.snippet: Anger at lockdowns and mask mandates provides fertile ground for arguments about the best way to fight the virus.
articles.abstract: Anger at lockdowns and mask mandates provides fertile ground for arguments about the best way to fight the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — If you’ve been following Gov. Mike DeWine’s coronavirus news conferences the way that New Yorkers follow Andrew Cuomo’s, you know Jack Windsor: He’s the reporter asking about creeping Marxism among contact tracers and suggesting that Ohio is double counting virus cases.

articles.headline: Europe Said It Was Pandemic-Ready. Pride Was Its Downfall.
articles.snippet: The coronavirus exposed European countries’ misplaced confidence in faulty models, bureaucratic busywork and their own wealth.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus exposed European countries’ misplaced confidence in faulty models, bureaucratic busywork and their own wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prof. Chris Whitty, Britain’s chief medical adviser, stood before an auditorium in a London museum two years ago cataloging deadly epidemics.

articles.headline: Businesses Are Supposed to Cut Debt in a Downturn. Why Not Now?
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s efforts to stabilize markets have touched off an even bigger borrowing binge than corporate America was already on.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s efforts to stabilize markets have touched off an even bigger borrowing binge than corporate America was already on.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, American corporations have taken advantage of historically low interest rates to gorge themselves on debt. Then came the pandemic and the sharpest economic downturn in history, which resulted in an odd solution for the companies that did all that borrowing: more debt.

articles.headline: ‘Less Optimistic’ and ‘More Cautious’: Top C.E.O.s Fret as Virus Cases Rise
articles.snippet: Many of the nation’s business leaders are steeling themselves for a period of prolonged economic disruption and the prospect of a slow, halting recovery.
articles.abstract: Many of the nation’s business leaders are steeling themselves for a period of prolonged economic disruption and the prospect of a slow, halting recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: With coronavirus cases around the country on the rise and states rolling back their reopening plans, many of the nation's top business leaders are steeling themselves for a period of prolonged economic disruption and the prospect of a slow, halting recovery.

articles.headline: A Rush to Use Black Art Leaves the Artists Feeling Used
articles.snippet: Black creative professionals say they have been used to lend legitimacy to diversity campaigns while being underpaid and pigeonholed.
articles.abstract: Black creative professionals say they have been used to lend legitimacy to diversity campaigns while being underpaid and pigeonholed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The streets of New York were crowded with protesters when Shantell Martin received an email from an ad agency last month.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Sandra E. Garcia

articles.headline: As Trump Slumps, Republican Donors Look to Save the Senate
articles.snippet: Senators and donors worry that with President Trump in trouble and the House probably out of reach, the Senate could be their last chance to hold power in Washington.
articles.abstract: Senators and donors worry that with President Trump in trouble and the House probably out of reach, the Senate could be their last chance to hold power in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.
